title: Why don't public schools seem to prepare students for college? - Quora

response.answer_text: After teaching college business courses (full-time) for 28 years, I’ve formed some strong opinions on this subject. But they are, of course, just opinions! And while many freshmen arrive on college campuses fully ready to handle their college classes, I believe that there are at least four inter-related reasons why so many students graduate from high school unprepared for college-level coursework: Lack of effective discipline in many K-12 classrooms (partly due to school administrators that don’t properly support teachers who try to enforce the rules). Unruly students make it much harder for the serious students to learn!Semi-involved parents who don’t ensure that their kids complete their homework assignments or study for tests; and who don’t support teachers who attempt to maintain the classroom discipline necessary to foster an effective learning environment.A bloated, mandated K-12 curriculum that often attempts to cover too many things that could (and should) be taught elsewhere by parents, grandparents, pastors, coaches, scout leaders, and other adult relatives, friends and neighbors who want to see kids grow up to be responsible and successful as adults. I believe that this bloated curriculum (plus other added responsibilities that teachers are now expected to shoulder) has reduced the classroom time spent teaching the (so-called) “3 Rs” — the necessary basics of Reading, Writing and Math that are prerequisites for academic success in college.And resulting — almost inevitably — from reasons 1 through 3 above are a significant number of incoming college freshmen:whose reading comprehension is so limited that they often don’t understand a lot of what they “read” in their textbooks — or can’t properly comprehend the meaning of many questions they see on tests;whose punctuation, grammar and spelling skills are so poor that many of the written assignments they submit border on being indecipherable;and whose basic math skills are often so deficient that it can be mind-boggling! For example, while teaching the most basic college business course (Business 101), I’ve often said something to students such as, “Imagine that you own a business that had $500,000 in sales last year and you ended up with $50,000 in profits. What was last year’s profit margin?” After seeing dozens of blank stares throughout the classroom, I’d give them some help by saying, “Just divide $50,000 by $500,000.” And after more blank stares (and watching several students pulling calculators out of their backpacks), I’d say, “You don’t need a calculator for this! It’s the same as 50 divided by 500 — or 10 divided by 100!” At that point (in a class of 35 students) a single timid voice might ask, “Is it 10%?” Since students usually took Business 101 a semester before taking Business 121 (aka “Business Math”), this sort of thing happened often enough that I began spending class time each semester teaching students some rudimentary math “shortcuts” — and how to do basic calculations like computing percentages. But needing to take time out of a college business course to cover grade school arithmetic definitely “bugged” me!So, while I may be wrong about whether or not I’ve identified all the “root causes” that underlie “why” so many freshmen do poorly during their first year in college, I believe that I’ve listed the majority of those reasons that can be traced back directly to the formative educational experiences that those struggling college students had prior to graduating from high school. But again, these are just my personal opinions!

Many public schools do well preparing students for college, so the question contains an over generalization. Some public schools don’t prepare students well for college. Reasons may include: Educational Gaps: Their pipeline of education from kindergarten through high school is weak. Students are promoted for social reasons rather than mastery of course content. This makes teaching in upper grades extremely difficult, since students aren’t able to perform at their official grade level. They lack the knowledge, skills, and abilities to perform in high school, so they are not ready for college.Parents: The parents do not have the skills or resources to compensate for poor public schools. They don’t have time or money for tutoring, high speed Internet, and supplemental readings. Thus, they can’t patch the holes in a student’s foundational knowledge so they can catch up and excel in higher grades.If parents have not attended college themselves, they don’t know how to tee their children up for the competitive process. They don’t know what to ask of the high school, and the high school doesn’t get a demand signal for college prep services.Resources: Schools are often funded by property tax revenues. Economically poor communities tend to cluster in Areas with lower assessments and thus less tax revenue. When schools are financially starved, they lack resources for facilities, technology, and extracurriculars. That affects the ability to attract and retain Highly skilled teachers. The poor schools are often plagued by low expectations for the students, who don’t get support or encouragement to excel and aspire to college. Available resources may go to remediation rather than achievement. Social order may also be wrapped up in gangs or crews that discourage academic achievement.
